text:
Nearly a decade ago, the IOM recommended reforming the system of reporting and tracking conflicts of interest in journals. It hasn't happened. 

The result: A mess, where leading medical figures misreport their conflicts. 

My story with @katie_thomas: https://www.propublica.org/article/prominent-doctors-industry-ties-disclosures-medical-journal-studies …

$68,436 in fiscal 2016 (https://seekingalpha.com/filing/3507649 )
$42,556 in fiscal 2017 (https://seekingalpha.com/filing/3986665 )
2/x

author: charlesornstein

text:
.@sloan_kettering has sent an important note to all staff after my story with @katie_thomas @nytimes in this morning's paper. "MSK and our faculty need to do a better job."

https://www.propublica.org/article/doctor-jose-baselga-cancer-researcher-corporate-financial-ties …
author: charlesornstein

text: According to our analysis with the @NYTimes, Dr. José Baselga — a towering figure in the cancer world — did not follow financial disclosure rules set by the American Association for Cancer Research when he was president of the group.
author: charlesornstein

text: Since 2013, Dr. Baselga disclosed no relationships in eight of 11 articles he authored or co-authored in Cancer Discovery, the @AACR journal he co-edits. Moreover, since then, he disclosed no relationships in 17 articles in @AACR’s Clinical Cancer Research.
author: charlesornstein

text: @adamfeuerstein
author: charlesornstein

text:
5/ If you just Google Dr. Baselga and any given company, you’ll find mentions of it. So what’s the big deal?

A. That’s not the way conflict of interest disclosure works. It’s supposed to be on all articles for which it is required.
author: charlesornstein

text:
4/ Why didn’t you note that Dr. Baselga did disclose his relationships in some articles?

A. We did say that. We said he didn’t disclose in 60% of articles from 2013-present. In two thirds of those 60%, other authors did disclose. (In 2017, he didn’t disclose in 87% of articles.)
author: charlesornstein

text:
3/ What’s the big deal?
A. As past president of a major cancer research group and current editor in chief of a medical journal, people look to Dr. Baselga to set the rules. If he doesn’t follow them, what message does it send?
author: charlesornstein

text:
2/ When you exclude the Seragon money, his industry earnings are minimal, no?
A. Not so. Beyond consulting fees, he earns a lot of money serving on boards. And many startups don’t disclose how much they pay doctors.   Also all ties are supposed to be disclosed.
author: charlesornstein

text:
1/ Isn’t it possible that Dr. Baselga just forgot to turn in a conflict of interest form?

A. It doesn’t work that way. Most journals require all authors to fill out the form, whether they have a disclosure or not. Meaning he had to write that he had no disclosures.
author: charlesornstein

text: 14/  If you are a patient at @CHI_StLukes or another Texas Medical Center hospital, tell us your experience: https://www.propublica.org/getinvolved/help-us-investigate-care-at-the-texas-medical-center … @Mike_Hixenbaugh @HoustonChron /end
author: charlesornstein

text: 13/ Where does this leave us? The hospital said its bypass surgery program has improved and that its heart transplant program will remain open. Our investigation continues.
author: charlesornstein

text: 12/ And we reported how from mid-2016 to mid-2017, @CHI_StLukes heart bypass outcomes were among the worst in the country. https://www.propublica.org/article/st-lukes-heart-bypass-surgery-complications … @HoustonChron @Mike_Hixenbaugh
author: charlesornstein

text: 11/ In the meantime, we’ve reported about a man who sued the hospital after he suffered brain damage during his heart transplant in 2016:
author: charlesornstein

text: 10/ A week later, Medicare said that it would stop paying for heart transplants on Aug. 17 because the hospital had not resolved its underlying problems.
author: charlesornstein

text: 9/ The hospital reopened the program saying it had made policy and staffing changes, but saying it found no systemic problems with the care the patients received.
author: charlesornstein

text: 8/ @CHI_StLukes suspended heart transplants for 14 days in June after two patients died following heart transplants in May. Another had died in March following a transplant in January. All told, three of nine heart transplant recipients this year died.
author: charlesornstein

text: 7/ @propublica and @houstonchronicle published our first piece in May, noting the outsized number of patient deaths and an exodus of physicians. We also reported on unusual complications and a widow who received an anonymous letter raising concerns.
author: charlesornstein

text: 6/ None of this received public attention. The hospital continued to market itself as having outcomes that were among the nation’s best--even though statistics showed otherwise.
author: charlesornstein

text: 5/ In the meantime, however, the hospital’s outcomes started to look statistically worse than expected when national transplant analysts reported results. That caught the eye of Medicare. In December 2017, an inspection said the hospital was out of compliance.
author: charlesornstein

text: 4/ The hospital hired a new transplant surgeon who began work in 2016 and it has said that results improved dramatically.
author: charlesornstein

text: 3/ In 2015, patient outcomes took a turn for the worse. Among 14 patients who received a heart transplant in the first six months of that year, five died in less than a year, far more than would be expected.
author: charlesornstein

text: 2/ @CHI_StLukes has played a historic role in heart care in this country. It was here that famed surgeon Denton Cooley performed some of the world’s first heart transplants back in the 1960s, and where his protégé, Dr. O.H. “Bud” Frazier, has pursued an artificial heart.
author: charlesornstein
